org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Simulation.name: Reintegration Exercise
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Simulation.blurb: A simulation to teach leadership in conflict environments.
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Simulation.introduction:
Welcome!

Please take a look around this web site and learn more about your characters and the other characters in the simulation. At this point, you should just be familiarizing yourself with this virtual world.

The schedule page (and/or your instructor) will alert you when the simulation moves into the next phase where you will be able to see and do more things.

Enjoy!
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Simulation.learningObjvs:
The primary objective of the simulation is to provide you a chance to apply concepts and practice skills related to the following course objectives:

  • Develop conflict transformation and communication skills necessary to effectively lead aspects of conflict management missions.
  • Understand the impact of an implementation across sectors and on the overall peace agreement , which learned through scenario decisions.
  • Establish team principles that will guide your joint actions in the field.
  • Experience the complexities of managing diverse teams operating in different cultural environments.
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Simulation.plannedPlayIdeas:
Instructor and Control Team Resources

During the simulation, the instructor will play the role of Simulation Control, four students will play the role of control team. Simulation Control and the control team will have four primary responsibilities:

Actions and Messages:
Monitor the actions that the participants are, or should be, taking and the messages they are sending. There are four primary areas the members of the task force need to manage:
  1. Ensure the IC and the reintegration process is running smoothly. Key questions:
    • Has the team opened the center?
    • Have they developed a strategy for handling the cash payments?
    • How are they handling other issues (corruption, security, etc.) being raised by the injects?)  
  2. Manage relationships with key stakeholders in the community. The stakeholder outreach plan from the Kabul meetings should be used a guide. At a minimum, there should be outreach to senior government officials (mayor, governor, etc.), tribal leaders, local community groups, local development organizations working in the region, and others identified in the group?s outreach plan. The type of injects used by Simulation Control and the control team should be closely tied to their activities regarding stakeholder outreach.Key questions:
    • How quickly are they responding to events on the ground?
    • Are they being proactive in reaching out to key stakeholders?
    • Are they implementing the stakeholder outreach plan from the Kabul meeting?  
  3. Manage communications with headquarters. Key questions:
    • How quickly are they responding to demands from HQ and events on the ground in regard to their communication with HQ?
    • Are they passing on the right amount of information?
    • Are they passing on information they shouldn?t be?  
  4. Maintain the effectiveness and coherence of the JRTF the team.
    • Has the team remained a team or are they working at cross-purposes?
    • Are they implementing the plan agreed to Kabul regarding how the task force will be organized?
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Simulation.aarStarterText:
In this last part of the simulation, a  joint After Action Report (AAR)
will be developed by simulation participants.

Each participant will prepare a section reviewing the simulation from the point of view of their actor, and will also contribute to an overview section.

From the point of view of your character, try to identify your unforeseen issues, successes, failures and lessons learned.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.name: DAI Rep JRTF
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.public__description:
Overview:

From the DAI website, www.dai.com

DAI delivers development. We do it in many of the world's most demanding environments, by integrating a broad range of disciplines. Over 40 years, our employee owners have built a forward-looking company ? one that combines innovative thinking, deep technical knowledge, and professional project management. We approach our work with passion, analytical rigor, and open minds. By freely sharing what we learn, we have built a reputation as thought leaders who translate good ideas into action and action into results. Our global team of 2,000 development professionals welcomes each opportunity to solve a new problem, no matter how difficult. That's how DAI has earned the trust of the clients, partners, and people who work alongside us all over the world.
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.semi__public__description:
Your Superiors:

DAI headquarters are located in Washington D.C., where the Afghanistan team, headed by a senior VP, oversees all the projects in the country There is also a large field office in Kabul, headed by the DAI Chief of Part for Afghanistan. Additionally, the task force itself is being overseen by the Joint NATO-UNAMA Reintegration Office (JNAD) in Kabul.
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.private__description:
Key Concerns
As the DAI representative to this project you have several key concerns:

For both your own reputation and the reputation of DAI, it is important that this project as well as the other DAI projects in Afghanistan are implemented successfully.
  • As a for profit entity, profitability is a key concern. Reducing costs and increasing efficiency is always a key concern.
  • DAI's most important donor is USAID. Maintaining good relations with USAID is crucial to DAI?s success both in Afghanistan and around the world.
  • Many of DAI?s projects in Afghanistan are in areas where security is uncertain. A good relationship with NATO and ISAF is crucial to be able to work in these areas,
  • While a good relationship with UNAMA and NAC is a positive, these relationships are not of paramount importance. UNAMA is a far less important actor in Afghanistan than NATO and the U.S.
  • As for NAC, you are concerned that they are in over the head on this project. While they have a long history in Afghanistan, their experience is primarily in advocacy and the implementation of small community projects. They don?t have experience implementing large complex projects such as this one.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.name: NAC Rep JRTF
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.public__description:
Norwegian Afghanistan Committee (NAC) Representative - Joint Reintegration Task Force
Overview (From the NAC website, www.afghanistan.no)

NAC is an independent development organization with no political or religious affiliation.
NAC offers help regardless of religion and ethnicity, and many of our projects are aimed at girls and women. Also, we are a green development organization with environmental projects.

NAC focuses on both long-term projects and short-term aid in Afghanistan and support two schools for girl-refugees in Peshawar, Pakistan. NAC started as a solidarity organization with the Afghan people after the Soviet invasion in 1979. However, it was not until 1986 our permanent presence in Afghanistan started. Since then our mission has expanded and today comprises developing projects in the areas of health, education, environment and infrastructure.

NAC's main foreign office is in Kabul and in addition we also have two regional offices in Jalalabad and Badakshan. NAC is a member organization with our members being able to take part in and influence our policies. A lot of our activities in Norway are based on voluntary work, and we have three local committees based in Oslo, Trondheim and Bergen. We also have a women's group working for the improvement of Afghan women's situation.
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.semi__public__description:
Superiors

NAC headquarters are located in Oslo, Norway, where programs in Afghanistan are overseen by the Program Director ? Central Asia. NAC also has a small office in Kabul, headed by the NAC Chief of Party, Afghanistan. Additionally, the task force itself is being overseen by the Joint NATO-UNAMA Reintegration Office (JNAD) in Kabul.
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.private__description:
Key Concerns

As the NAC representative to this project, you have several key concerns:
  • It is important for your career and the NAC for the project to be successfully implemented. However, NAC defines success as not simply the number of militants disarmed, but how successfully the community as a whole reintegrates the militants.
  • Many NAC projects throughout Afghanistan are implemented in close coordination with community leaders. Therefore, maintaining a strong relationship with the community in Uzzdwaadi is important.
  • While UNAMA is not a large donor, NAC's key donors are in close contact and continuously coordinate with the United Nations in Afghanistan and elsewhere. Therefore it is important you maintain a strong relationship with UNAMA.
  • Related to several of these key concerns is maintaining a reputation as being independent of both the U.S. and particularly the ISAF military forces.
  • You realize that NAC is quite small in comparison with DAI. However, you believe that NAC has much more intimate knowledge of Afghanistan society. Moreover, you believe that DAI, while they have done good work is always primarily concerned with their profits as opposed to the communities in which they work. Therefore it is very important to you that NAC continues to work on the project and is a key player in important decisions.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.name: UNAMA Rep JRTF
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.public__description:
Overview:

From the UNAMA website, www.unama-afg.org:

UNAMA coordinates all activities of the UN system in the country and works for the establishment of strong and sustainable Afghan institutions. The framework for cooperation between the Government of Afghanistan, the United Nations and the international community is outlined by the Afghanistan Compact, a blueprint for working towards peace and security, rule of law, good governance, human rights protection and sustainable economic and social development over a five-year period. The Compact was launched on 31 January 2006.

There are a number of guidelines that characterize the work of UNAMA: all activities of the UN system are coordinated and the programme of work is determined by Afghan needs and priorities; the Mission aims at having as many nationals as possible in posts that traditionally have been occupied by expatriates; capacity-building is a cardinal principle and UNAMA works towards the establishment of strong and sustainable Afghan institutions - in that context its ultimate goal is to work itself out of a job.

UNAMA's priorities include strengthening Afghan institutions and building the capacity of the Afghan Administration at all levels, including the development of institutions of good governance, of law and order, and of security. Emphasis is also given to increasing employment and cash for work schemes, which provide income to families.
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.semi__public__description:
Reporting Structure: UNAMA Representative to the JRTF

UNAMA has a large office in Kabul. The Security Sector Office, under the leadership of the Deputy Special Representative for Afghanistan has responsibility for this project. As the result of the partnership with NATO, this project has a relatively high profile, and has been a pet project of Special Representative for Afghanistan and Head of UNAMA.

Additionally, the task force itself is being overseen by the Joint NATO-UNAMA Reintegration Office (JNAD) in Kabul.
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.private__description:
Key Concerns

As the UNAMA representative, you have the following key concerns:

  • It is important to you that UNAMA be a key player in regard to reintegration programs specifically and development programs in Afghanistan more generally. It is your belief that eventually NATO troops will withdraw, so UNAMA must start to be seen as the lead actor in programs like this.
  • You see UNAMA's role as improving the situation of Afghan communities. Therefore, you are most concerned about community relations and strengthening social capital within the communities in which the reintegration program is operating.
  • Due to past events, UNAMA is very concerned about fiscal accountability. It is clear that your superiors will want a very thorough accounting of how program monies were spent.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.name: NATO Rep JRTF
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.public__description:
Overview

From the NATO website, www.nato.int/issues/afghanistan/index.html:

The Alliance's aim is to help establish the conditions in which Afghanistan can enjoy ( after decades of conflict, destruction and poverty ) a representative government and self-sustaining peace and security.

NATO's role is a key part of the Afghanistan Compact, a five-year plan between the government of Afghanistan and the international community, which sets goals relating to the security, governance and economic development of the country.
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.semi__public__description:
NATO's engagement is three-fold:

  • through leadership of the UN-mandated International Security Assistance Force (ISAF), an international force of some 52,700 troops (including National Support Elements) that assists the Afghan authorities in extending and exercising its authority and influence across the country, creating the conditions for stabilisation and reconstruction
  • a Senior Civilian Representative, responsible for advancing the political-military aspects of the Alliance?s commitment to the country, who works closely with ISAF, liaises with the Afghan government and other international organizations, and maintains contacts with neighboring countries.
  • a substantial programme of cooperation with Afghanistan, concentrating on defence reform, defence institution-building and the military aspects of security sector reform.
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.private__description:
Your Superiors

You report to U.S. Army Colonel Richard Tarken, head of civil affairs for the NATO International Security Assistance Force (ISAF). Colonel Tarken is located in Kabul at NATO ISAF HQ. Additionally, the task force itself is being overseen by the Joint NATO-UNAMA Reintegration Office (JNAD) in Kabul.

Key Concerns

  • As the NATO representative to the project, you have several key concerns:
  • Of overriding importance is to maximize the number of militants that are disarmed. Every militant that is disarmed makes the military mission of ISAF that much easier.
  • It is crucial to ensure that those who receive the reintegration packages are actually militants and that they remain demobilized. Many in the military are already suspicious of the Civil Affairs strategy of paying militants to disarm. Stories indicating that militants have taken money, but continue to fight could make it difficult of NATO to continue to participate in these types of programs.
  • As the military member of the task force, you feel responsibility for ensuring the security of the team. Good relations with the community are key in order to gain solid intelligence on potential security threats.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.name: Control
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.Actor.public__description: Simulation Control. This actor represents all external parties and the headquarters of each of the organizations represented in the simulation.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.SimulationPhase.name: Started
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.SimulationPhase.notes:
The first phase of the simulation.
In this phase,
  • The players will read their background information, and
  • The control player will enter the player's scenario plans.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.SimulationPhase.name: The Kabul Meeting
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.SimulationPhase.notes:
An internal, strategic planning process within the task force in Kabul - players will produce plans for implementation in Uzzdwaadi.
  • The players will generate their team documents while communicating via chat.
  • The control player will monitor events.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.SimulationPhase.name: Pre-Implementation
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.SimulationPhase.notes:
Player documents have been created. Simulation action is frozen until implementation phase begins.
  • One could think of this as the travel phase out to Uzzdwaadi.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.SimulationPhase.name: Implementation in Uzzdwaadi
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.SimulationPhase.notes:
In this phase of the simulation, you, along with your colleagues in the Joint Reintegration Task Force, will be managing a reintegration program in the fictional Afghanistan town of Uzzdwaadi.
  • Control will inform the players of the events unfolding around them.
  • The players will tell control how they are responding to them.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.SimulationPhase.name: Reflection
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.SimulationPhase.notes:
A time for player to reflect on all that has happened.
  • Players will enter in their thoughts on how the simulation went and what they learned.
  • Control will be able to read the player entries and work on the final After Action Report.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.SimulationPhase.name: Completed
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.SimulationPhase.notes:
The last phase of the simulation.
  • Players will be able to read the final After Action Report.

org.usip.osp.communications.InjectGroup.name: To JRTF
org.usip.osp.communications.InjectGroup.description: Injects seen by all four members of the Joint Reintegration Task Force

org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__text:
To: Uzzdwaadi JRTF
From: IC Staff
Re: Letter from TRIBAL Leaders

We have received a letter from a group of 15 tribal leaders in the Uzzdwaadi region. The letter reads in part: "When the rest of our community is suffering deprivation and hardship, it is unacceptable that any resources should be given to those that left our community and created havoc in our country." It appears that the letter has also been released to the media.

org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__name: JRTF-02 Letter from Uzzdwaadi Women's Rights Organization
org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__text:
To: Uzzdwaadi JRTF
From: IC Staff
Re: Letter from Uzzdwaadi Women's Rights Organization

The IC has received a letter from a local Women's Rights Organization demanding that the widows and children of militants killed in the fighting be given the same incentive packages as the demobilized militants. The letter indicates that they have copied the letter to all female parliamentarians in Kabul and released it to the media.

To: Uzzdwaadi JRTF
From: Joint NATO-UNAMA Reintegration Office (JNAD) - Kabul
Re: Uzzdwaadi reintegration effort.

Your task force arrived in Uzzdwaadi a few days ago. So far the logistics of the operation have run smoothly. You have established an office in a secure compound at the outskirts of the town. You also have obtained space for a small Intake Center (IC) one block away in which the initial contact with militants wishing to demobilize and reintegrate will take place. The office will primarily be staffed by two Afghanis that you brought with you from Kabul. You have also hired two local security guards to work at the IC Your best information indicates that several militants will present themselves at the IC when it is opened.
org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__notes: Note to Instructor: This opening message should be revised to reflect what was decided in Phase 1 of the simulation, and should be on screen or sent immediately at the beginning of Phase 2, Implementation in Uzzdwaadi

org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__text:
To: Uzzdwaadi JRTF
From: Simulation Control
Re: JRTF Orientation

As a group, the JRTF can send a message from the task force to any external individual or organization. As a group, the JRTF can take any actions it deems appropriate. During the exercise, Simulation Control will review all actions taken. If it is deemed that the JRTF has the capacity to take such an action, it will be approved.

To: Uzzdwaadi JRTF
From: Simulation Control
Re: JRTF Orientation (continued)

Any individual in the task force can send a message from the task force to any external individual or organization. These are sent in the individual's professional capacity. Task force members can also, at any time, communicate privately with other members of the task force. Any individual in the task force can take any actions it deems appropriate. Simulation control will review all actions taken. If it is deemed that the individual has the capacity to take such an action, it will be approved. When the simulation begins, you will receive an opening message from the control team. At this point you should begin to implement your strategy, as decided on at the Kabul meeting.

To: Uzzdwaadi JRTF
From: Joint NATO-UNAMA Reintegration Office (JNAD) - Kabul
Re: Uzzdwaadi reintegration effort.

Initial reports indicate that your logistical start-up has gone smoothly. Please provide immediate updates regarding any problems. Yesterday's meeting between Kandahar task force members and tribal leaders went poorly. Tribal leaders are demanding the office and Intake Center be shutdown. Recommend begin outreach to community immediately.

To:Uzzdwaadi JRTF
From: Joint NATO-UNAMA Reintegration Office (JNAD) - Kabul
Re: Magazine interview

A statement has been released by senior Taliban leadership through the Indian news magazine, Frontline. ?We have seen that some so-called mujahideen in the Uzzdwaadi region are following the example of Karzai and becoming U.S. stooges. This is not going to make life easier for the U.S. or Karzai because thee so-called mujahideens are `paper-tigers'. The real mujahideens will continue to fight Karzai and his master - the U.S. Karzai's days are numbered. Very soon, our mujahideens, the real mujahideens will get him.

To:Uzzdwaadi JRTF
From: IC Staff
Re: Militants Killed

Reports have arrived at the IC that two militants in the reintegration program have been found murdered in a field just outside of Uzzdwaadi. Afghan National Police are investigating. You have also hired two local security guards to work at the IC. Several militants presented themselves at the IC when it opened. You may begin your reintegration program. Please advise control on how you will proceed.

To:Uzzdwaadi JRTF
From: IC Staff
Re: Militants wishing to turn themselves in.

We have received the following message signed by six individuals. We will agree to turn ourselves and our weapons in if we receive complete and total amnesty.
org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__notes: Note: Can change the militant's demands to something else that would violate the task force's code of conduct.

org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__text:
To: Uzzdwaadi JRTF
From: Simulation Control
Re: Call from the Mayor of Uzzdwaadi

The JRTF received a call from the Mayor of Uzzdwaddi. He said that the mayor's office has received numerous reports that the intake officers are demanding a kickback of $50 in order to ensure that former militants be accepted into the program. He is demanding that the staff members be fired and two members of his staff, who he guarantees are trustworthy, be hired to staff the IC.

To: Uzzdwaadi JRTF
From: Simulation Control
Re: Call from the Office of the Governor of Uzzdwaadi

The JRTF received a call from the governor's office of Uzzdwaadi. The governor is requesting a meeting with the head of the task force.
org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__notes: Note: initially this is a test of their ability to respond quickly and choose a member of the task force to meet with the governor. Other issues can be raised during this meeting.

org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__text:
To: Uzzdwaadi JRTF
From: UNAMA - Kabul
Re: Message from MRRD

The UNAMA office in Kabuli has received a formal complaint from the Ministry of Rural Reconstruction and Development that [CONTROL INSERT SPECIFIC ACTIVITY] of the JRTF violates the letter and the spirit of the Afghanistan National Development Strategy (ANDS). UNAMA requests that the activities of the JRTF be brought in line with the ANDS.
org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__notes: CONTROL INSERT SPECIFIC ACTIVITY above before sending

org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__text:
To: Uzzdwaadi JRTF
From: NATO-UNAMA Reintegration Office (JNAD) - Kabul
Re: ISAF operation

ISAF forces, led by U.S. Army Rangers, launched a moonlight operation in a village on the Pakistan border 20 miles from Uzzdwaadi. ISAF claims 15 militants on their way back to Pakistan were killed. News organizations are reporting claims that seven civilians in the village were killed including two children.

To: Uzzdwaadi JRTF
From: IC Staff
Re: Attack on IC

This afternoon shots were fired from a passing car at the IC. No one was hurt, but one of several of the windows were shattered.

org.usip.osp.communications.InjectGroup.name: To UNAMA Rep
org.usip.osp.communications.InjectGroup.description: Injects visible to the UNAMA Representative to the Joint Reintegration Task Force

org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__text:
To: UNAMA Representative - JRTF
From: UNAMA - Kabul
Re: Funding Delays

This is to inform you that the additional $1.5 million in funding committed to the reintegration program will likely be delayed as member countries have been slow to contribute to the reintegration fund.
org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__notes: Your recent promise of disbursement may take some time.

org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__text:
To: UNAMA Representative - JRTF
From: UNAMA - Kabul
Re: De-mining operations

This is to inform you that regrettably we can no longer support de-mining as an alternative for reintegrated militants. The funding for UNMACA has not been renewed.

To: UNAMA Representative - JRTF
From: UNAMA - Kabul
Re: NATO Security Procedures.

We note with great alarm the recent moves of NATO to increase security at the JRTF Intake Center. If this security remains, the program will likely be seen as a military program by the community. Recommend increased community outreach efforts and outreach to NATO to request that security presence be reduced.

To: UNAMA Representative - JRTF
From: UNAMA - Kabul
Re: Pace of reintegration efforts.

We recently received a letter from several government officials in the Uzzdwaadi area complaining about the reintegration program. Their primary complaint was that former militants were receiving cash payments of up to US$500. Recommend you slow reintegration process until more community outreach can be done.

To:UNAMA Representative - JRTF
From: UNAMA - Kabul
Re: Funding Streams for reintegration program.

The finance director here is concerned that monies from the reintegration program are mixing with DAI and NAC funds from other sources. We request that you alert DAI and NAC that an audit of these funds will be required by UNAMA at the end of the program.
org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__notes: Alternatively: If another group tried to be flexible with finances. HQ sends a stern note, that new monies cannot be applied to the project without proper approvals from UNAMA - Kabul.

org.usip.osp.communications.InjectGroup.name: To NAC Rep
org.usip.osp.communications.InjectGroup.description: Messages to NAC Representative to the JRTF

org.usip.osp.communications.Inject.inject__text:
To: NAC Representative - JRTF
From: NAC Chief of Party - Kabul
Re: Message from Program Directors

I have received a message from two program directors from important NAC programs in Afghanistan. They are concerned about former militants being integrated into existing programs. There is a real chance that the controversy surrounding the reintegration program will negatively impact existing programs. What can I tell them about the vetting process that may assuage their concerns?

To: NAC Representative - JRTF
From: NAC Chief of Party - Kabul
Re: Board of Director's Concerns

We have received a message from NAC HQ-Oslo that indicates that the Board of Directors is very concerned about NAC's involvement in a program in which the U.S. military is involved. Please report immediately on the nature of military participation in the program.

To: NAC Representative - JRTF
From: NAC Chief of Party - Kabul
Re: Msg from NAC HQ-Oslo

We have received a message from NAC HQ- Oslo that indicates the NADC is not happy. The NADC is reporting that several of its implementing partners on various NADC-funded programs in the area are complaining vehemently about the large cash payments that former militants are receiving. Several local NGOs have indicated that they can no longer work with the Norwegian NGOs as a result.

To: DAI Representative - JRTF
From: DAI Chief of Party Kabul
Re: Message from HQ regarding U.S. Congressmen

We received a message form DAI HQ-Washington indicating that several congressmen have issued letters of protest to USAID regarding the reintegration program in Afghanistan. Their protest indicates that no U.S. money should go to organizations engaged in programs that provide "amnesty to terrorists". What can I tell them to assuage their concerns?

To: DAI Representative - JRTF
From: DAI Program Director - Uzzdwaadi
Re: Message from Tribal Leaders

As you know I am a program director that oversees multiple workforce development and livelihood projects. We have had several contacts with tribal leaders indicating that they will fully support the reintegration program if two community members can enter the training program for every former militant.

To: DAI Representative - JRTF
From: DAI Chief of Party - Kabul
Re: Emphasis on Program Packages

We have been looking at the numbers from the reintegration program. We want to encourage you to promote the adoption of the demining or vocational training packages by the reintegrates. Both the enterprise support and agricultural packages are far more expensive for DAI to operate.

To: DAI Representative - JRTF
From: DAI Chief of Party - Kabul
Re: Reintegration Pace

We have been looking at the numbers from the reintegration program. We want to encourage you to increase the numbers of reintegrates. There are relatively high fixed costs for this program so we need to increase the number of militants in the program in order to make it more profitable..

To: DAI Representative - JRTF
From: DAI Chief of Party - Kabul
Re: New funding for project.

We have received indications from USAID - Washington that they can release an additional $2 million for the reintegration program through a USDA funding mechanism. Please alert other members of the task force that these monies will be added to the budgets of the DAI reintegration programs which are part of the JRTF project.

To: NATO Representative - JRTF
From: ISAF Field Commander
Re: Taliban Message

We have received a message from the Taliban demanding that all reintegration efforts in the region cease. If this is not done, attacks on foreign installations and government offices in Uzzdwaadi will increase. The message has been authenticated as coming from the Taliban. The message has been forwarded to ISAF HQ as well.

To: NATO Representative - JRTF
From: Civil Affairs - ISAF HQ
Re: Security

Given recent events and intelligence reports, we are ordering a contingent of eight NATO soldiers to guard the IC and surrounding areas. The contingent will initially be U.S. soldiers and will eventually be replaced by a French contingent.

To: NATO Representative - JRTF
From: Civil Affairs - ISAF HQ
Re: Capture of Militants

Be advised that two militants acting as forward scouts for Taliban infiltrators from Pakistan were captured. It has been ascertained that these individuals are participants in the reintegration program. Please report on vetting process and possible improvements to said process.

To: NATO Representative - JRTF
From: Civil Affairs - NATO, Kabul
Re: Pace of Reintegration Process

We are concerned about the slow pace of reintegration process. Please make every effort to increase number of militants being reintegrated.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.BaseSimSection.description: An 'after action report' (AAR) is a document written after an event describing what happened and what the lessons learned were. Adding this section to a simulation adds a page showing the after action report that the instructor has written. This is generally considered the essential final step of a simulation: to provide feedback to the players on how they have done, and give them thoughts to reflect upon.
A section to allow the game controller to change the phase of a simulation.
A section to see all in game emails, and get and receive emails.
A section to mark the simulation as terminated and move it into its final phase.
The introductory text will be shown here.
A section to make broadcast announcements.
A section to allow the control player to push out events (injects) to all of the players.
A section to display announcments to the players.
A section to view the player reflections.
A section to write the after action report.
A place for the players to read the schedule.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.CustomizeableSe.bigString:
In this phase you will attempt to implement your plans.

Tip: Don't Fight the Scenario

Although the simulation is based on real events, it is a fictional situation that has been constructed to support the learning objectives. Accept the scenario as it is and develop your strategy accordingly.

Below are brief explanations of some of the more important tabs you will see in this section.

  • Communications - On this tab you will be able to send emails to your Head Quarters and other parties. You will also be able to chat in your teams chat room. This can be used to vet ideas with Control as well as document the conversation among team members
  • External Memos - Formal memo style communication with any external parties (such as indigenous organizations or media outlets) meeting requests, memorandum of understanding, etc. - note that control may respond to your communiques with a simulated reaction the external group
  • Announcements - Important messages.
  • Team Documents - Team Principles, Strategic Communication Plan, Conflict Transformation Strategy for reference and/or to cut and paste into memos, etc.
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.CustomizeableSe.description: A page that will only display text. One of these pages can be a placeholder for pages that require more advanced programming.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.CustomizeableSe.bigString: Below are listed alphabetically all of the current Actors that you can see.
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.CustomizeableSe.description: A section to allow players see information about themselves, and public information about the other actors in this simulation.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.CustomizeableSe.bigString:
Please use this time to answer the following questions.


Did the simulation reinforce learning in the course?

What did you learn from the simulation?

What did you learn from the course?

Did something surprise you?
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.CustomizeableSe.description: A section to allow the players to express their impressions, defend their actions, etc.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.CustomizeableSe.bigString:
Welcome to the Kabul Meetings phase.

In this Phase you will work on 3 documents with your fellow students.
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.CustomizeableSe.description: A page that will only display text. One of these pages can be a placeholder for pages that require more advanced programming.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.CustomizeableSe.bigString:
Welcome!

In this 'frozen phase' all you can do is see the documents that your team has previously written.

You can consider this phase to represent your traveling from Kabul out to your village of Uzzdwaadi.
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.CustomizeableSe.description: A page that will only display text. One of these pages can be a placeholder for pages that require more advanced programming.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.CustomizeableSe.bigString: In this room you may communicate with the actors listed.
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.CustomizeableSe.description: A page to allow several actors to communicate privately.
A page that can show one section on the left, and one on the right.
A section to pass memos back and forth from HQ.
A section to read a document or documents.

A section to allow a player to write a document. This document can be any time in nature, a report, a memorandum of understanding, etc. After adding a document to be written by a player, it will probably be necessary to add it as a document that can be read.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.CustomizeableSe.bigString:
The setting of this simulation is a medium-sized town, known asUzzdwaadi,in the region ofUzzdwaadiin eastern Afghanistan.Once a stronghold of both al-Qaeda and the Taliban, Uzzdwaadi, is now often referred to as the "provincial model for success" by U.S. and Afghan officials. A collaborative effort between local officials and NATO-led. military forces has restored a tenuous calm to the area and driven the Taliban largely underground or across the border, 25 miles away, into Pakistan. Despite the relative calm NATO installations and government offices still suffer attacks from militants who are believed to maintain safe havens in Pakistan.

The gains in security have allowed several military-led, short-term impact efforts to proceed, including: roadbuilding projects, the building of schools, agriculture projects, and water and sanitation projects. The consideration of long-term democratic and economic development efforts and social well-being programs is regarded crucial to solidifying the security gains in the area.

In the simulation, you are representing your organization on a task force that emerged out of a joint UNAMA-NATO effort to provide technical and material assistance in areas that are experiencing spontaneous demobilizations by former militants. This effort has also emerged as a result of pressure from within NATO countries to increase their reliance on non-military means of countering insurgency and improving stability. The goal of the task force is to facilitate a process by which these militants, who are primarily low and medium-ranking soldiers, are reintegrated into their communities in a sustainable way. 

Your task force has been assigned toUzzdwaadi. In the past six months, numerous reports have been coming in that militants in the area have been communicating to both domestic and international actors that they are willing to lay down their arms. This, in addition to the strategic and symbolic importance ofUzzdwaadi, has made this particular effort a high priority within both UNAMA and NATO. The task force has the full backing of UNAMA and NATO, and believe they have the support of the governor ofUzzdwaadi.

Your task force consists of four individuals: 

  • A U.S. military civil affairs officer who been serving with NATO in Kabul. 
  • A UNAMA official. 
  • A contractor employed by DAI Associates, a Washington DC-based development organization that is funded by the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID). DAI has been implementing large USAID projects in eastern Afghanistan for several years. 
  • A representative of the Norwegian Afghanistan Committee (NAC), a Norwegian based NGO, which has been implementing Norway Agency for Development Cooperation-funded projects in the area. 

Due to the need to move rapidly, funding for the task force has been allocated by USAID and the Norway Agency for Development Cooperation (NADC) through existing funding mechanisms with DAI Associates and the Norwegian Afghanistan Committee (NAC).
org.usip.osp.baseobjects.CustomizeableSe.description: A page that will only display text. One of these pages can be a placeholder for pages that require more advanced programming.

org.usip.osp.baseobjects.CustomizeableSe.bigString:
As  part of the process that created the task force, UNAMA and NATO have agreed on  a reintegration package that the task force can distribute to former militants.  It consists of the following:

  1. Two cash payments of $150 per  individual. The timing of these payments is at the discretion of the task  force.
    2.  
  2. A choice of four reintegration packages. 

a.) Agriculture

The standard agricultural packages were  developed in consultation with the Ministry of Agriculture and Animal  Husbandry. The following options were devised: nursery development, fisheries,  livestock distribution or a package of seeds, tools and fertilizer.

b.) Vocational Training

The standard package includes training in one of  several trades, e.g. carpentry, masonry, tailoring, and a basic set of the  relevant tools.

c.) Small Enterprise Support

For individuals wishing to start or  build up a business, the standard package includes business training courses, a  small grant and continued assistance with their undertaking.

d.) De-Mining

With the help of the United Nations  Mine Action Centre for Afghanistan (UNMACA), a de-mining training program has  been developed. After completing de-mining training ex-combatants are referred  to de-mining agencies for employment.

The  training and career support aspects of the program will be managed by DAI and  NAC and will be integrated into their existing portfolios of development  projects.

The  task force has also been provided with a limited reintegration fund to use as  it sees fit to secure the long-term success of militant reintegration with the  community. US$2 million has been pledged, of which $500,000 has been delivered,  in the coming year by Norway and the UK. This money will be in addition to the  money in the operational budget provided by USAID and NADC.

In previous areas,  the logistics of the demobilization plan have worked as follows. Militants  wishing to demobilize present themselves at an Intake Center (IC) staffed by  local Afghanis. They are asked to return in a week to begin the program, during  which time research is conducted to ensure they are who they say they are and  that they are suitable candidates for reintegration. In some cases community  members have been brought into this research process, in other cases not. Once  they are cleared to enter the program, they are immediately eligible to receive  cash payments and begin training. When they receive the cash payments is at the  discretion of the task force.
